captions.text:
We all know that light bends when it travels
through glass, water, or other transparent

material - that's how a microscope, lighthouse
and spectacles work!

And you might even know that light bends because
it travels slower through glass or water than

through air - but why does light slow down?
And how does it speed up again when it comes

out on the other side? There's nothing there
to give it a push!

Well, if you think light is a wave, it's easy
to explain - electromagnetic waves simply

travel slower through glass than through air.
So the wave crests are closer to each other,

but the light still oscillates the same number
of times per second - it stays the same color.

When the wave hits the air again, its color
stays the same, while its crests spread out

and it returns to light speed. The simplified
explanation is that the energy of a wave is

determined by its frequency, or color, which
doesn't change! So it doesn't need a boost
to speed up at the other side.

But wait, you say! I thought light traveled
at the same speed in every reference frame

- you still haven't explained how it can slow
down! Well, now let's think about light as

a particle. When light goes through glass,
it gets knocked around and bumps into all

sorts of molecules and electrons. So whenever
it's traveling, it's traveling at the speed

of light - but it's busy interacting with
and scattering off lots of stuff along the

way, and it doesn't necessarily take the shortest
path through the glass.

It's like the President of the United States
trying to cross a room – if the room is

empty, he can walk across directly. But if
the room is full of people all of whom want

to shake the President's hand, even though
he walks from person to person at full "Presidential-speed",

he'll get slowed down along the way. As soon
as he reaches the far side of the room, though,
he's free to resume his pace.
Full speed ahead, Mr. President!

title: The Speed of Light in Glass

comments.text:
Light does not slow down when traveling through a medium. It oscillates 
differently and can be filtered, but it is either stopped or keeps 
traveling at C. Because if it was slowed down, it would no longer have 
light properties and become "mass"﻿
comments.author: John Crapper

comments.text: Light in air :3.0x10^8 m/s      Light in glass is: 2.0x10^8﻿
comments.author: Dank memes

comments.text:
So basically (correct me if i'm wrong) the speed of light (c) i always the 
same but when it passes through glass for example it still has the same 
speed but only takes a bit longer for it to come out to the other end. 
Which means that the speed of light is always constant no matter what, but 
only takes a bit more time to get through a different medium. Right?﻿
comments.author: Apollo Inc.

comments.text:
Yes, you are what 100% correct. Light never slows down. It APPEARS to slow 
down but it just takes a longer path through the medium. Light always takes 
the fastest route.
comments.author: Gibraun Mitchell

comments.text:
Cars cannot turn without decelerating in one direction and accelerating in 
another, so I fear they may make a poor example to someone who might 
already be confused.

Perhaps think classical UFOs instead. They can turn without losing any 
speed at all, but the one that takes a straight path will still travel 
farther from its starting point than the one that zig-zags around.

And yes, IceFroggy, you are correct, although you're only describing the 
overall outcome and not what's happening at each step along the way. Eric 
phrased it best, I think: It takes a longer path.
comments.author: Fal Leithani

comments.text:
Another way to look at it is this:

Imagine a car travelling at 60 km/h (or if you're American, 60 mi/h), 
through a straight autobahn.  Imagine another car travelling at the same 
speed but is driving through a zigzag road.  Which IS faster?  Which 
APPEARS faster (from a reference point)?

comments.author: Jonny Brooks

comments.text:
No.
Light waves experience the doppler effect.
From a stationary standpoint, the light slowly becomes more blue the faster 
the object moves towards you.
The light will then become red shifted as the object moves away from you.
This is the same with sound.
The light itself will not move faster, but instead get kind of "crunched".

comments.author: failatlife1

comments.text:
+failatlife1 Why not? Special Relativity states that physics is the same if 
the reference frame is moving at a constant velocity. If using the equation 

                    v(1) + v(2)

v(3) =   ---------------------------------

             /                           \
            /   v(1) x v(2)            \
       1 - |  -----------------            |
            \    (speed of light)^2 /
             \                            / 


then the light will be moving about 1000.001 mph faster than the speed of 
light.

comments.text:
so is the speed of light in highly  precise and repetitive crystaline 
structures higher than in less perfect media?

that doesnt make sense, since if they are the most refractive, the speed of 
light must be slower in that medium. That means more banging and careening 
about for the photons inside the crystal, yet you can see images through 
them clearly.

You are probably right, but I am so far not able to convince myself, or 
imagine what is going on on the particle/wave level.
comments.author: pizzacrusher

comments.text:
Well, ask yourself what properties highly transparent matter has which its 
less-transparent counterparts do not. That's where you'll find your answer. 
Transparent materials tend to be much less dense and/or are organized into 
extremely repetitive and precisely-angled crystalline structures, much like 
a carefully and precisely aligned hall of mirrors.

In fact, the more dense a material is, the more precise and flawless the 
crystal needs to be for light to be able pass through cleanly. And by no 
coincidence, such denser crystals also tend to refract the light passing 
through them much more than their less-dense counterparts.

comments.text:
If this explanation was correct then light would scatter in all directions 
in glass and come out at strange angles.   However we know that a laser 
beam travelling through a cube of glass will still come out the other side 
as a straight beam.  Even the Professors on Sixty Symbols channel seem to 
struggle with a good explanation of this phenomena, their Classical or 
Quantum explanations are both models that have weaknesses, so perhaps a 
clear understanding of this phenomena is still waiting for discovery.﻿

comments.text:
The part about light slowing down as it bounces off of molecules makes no 
sense. Glass molecules are scattered randomly, so every photon could bounce 
off a different number of molecules, thus some photons would be trapped in 
glass longer than others, and there is 0 % of chance that a photon would 
not change direction after hitting all those molecules, which means that 
the light would be all distorted after leaving the glass or whatever it 
went through. There has to be another explanation for that.﻿
comments.author: filipivetic

comments.text:
actually glass is curved for that purpose...ie telescope lenses. And also 
different hardness levels will give different diffraction properties of 
light. glass scatters light! It has to be curved to concentrate it!
comments.author: Roy Hemion

comments.text:
So he has it right to some extent. I think it might help to know that there 
are multiple reasons that the individual photon's in a stream of light slow 
down or change position when passing through matter. However, the speed of 
a photon alone never changes it is always c. Try to imagine pouring a 
bucket of small round pellets overtop of a couple larger pellets... sort 
of.. In any case some of those photon's are reacting with the atoms and it 
causes them to do strange things; however, if you think about it light is 
distorted after it goes through glass. Hence shadows and refraction.. 
reflection these kinds of things. Other objects with mass completely stop 
light or absorbe all of it others bend it.

Watching this, it suddenly popped into my head that the shape of the 
prism-which gets wider from the tip to the base-means the light particles 
encounter different amounts of resistance throughout the structure of the 
prism, which is why all of the different colors of light come out the other 
end as opposed to just two or three of the colors. So I wonder how 
precisely angled the prism has to be to result in a rainbow...

comments.text:
Actually, lambda is shorter in the resulting wave, and thus, the group

comments.author: meddelhed

comments.text:
That was incorrect. Light gets slower in matter because: a) It stimulates 
the electrons to oscillate with its own frequency b) These electrons emit 
light with the same frequency, but of course not in phase c) All electrons 
do that, and the resulting wave is a superposition of the "newly emitted" 
and the "original" wave. The speed of light in matter then is the group 
velocity v_g = c/n and, since v_g = lambda * f, the wavelength must also 
get shorter
